I spent time in a Roma community outside Pristina, Kosovo. A Greek NGO had 
built two large housing blocks for them, though about half of them lived in 
small houses, and a few in dilapidated barracks. The conditions in the 
barracks were atrocious, with standing water on the floor and dogs living 
in the rooms with the children. These Roma had been kicked out of Pristina 
in 2000- along with the Serbs- and were resettled at the base of a filthy 
power-plant. The Roma speak Serbian (SCBM), which makes them unpopular with 
the Kosovar Albanians; they are also Muslims, which makes them no friends 
of the Serbs. A truly unenviable position.

The Roma treated me very well while I was in their homes. A few families 
invited me in for tea and a chat. It was nice.

My experiences with Roma have been mixed. I have had a few nice encounters, 
but have also seen plenty of aggressive pan-handling and begging. Plenty of 
European friends have told me about the petty theft that usually 
accompanies Roma. There is a major emphasis on Roma issues within the 
"international community" and plenty of projects to build housing, provide 
schooling, etc. There is definitely discrimination, but also a legitimate 
frustration at the lack of will on the Roma's part to integrate.﻿

The first World Romani Congress was organized in 1971 in Orpington near 
London, England, United Kingdom, funded in part by the World Council of 
Churches and the Government of India. It was attended by 23 representatives 
from nine nations (Czechoslovakia, Finland, Norway, France, Great Britain, 
Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Spain and Yugoslavia) and observers from 
Belgium, Canada, India and the United States.[1] Five sub-commissions were 
created to examine social affairs, education, war crimes, language, and 
culture. At the congress, the green and blue flag from the 1933 conference 
of the General Association of the Gypsies of Romania,[2] embellished with 
the red, sixteen-spoked chakra, was reaffirmed as the national emblem of 
the Roma people, and the song "Gelem, Gelem" was adopted as the Roma 
anthem. Usage of the word "Roma" (rather than variants of "gypsy") was also 
accepted by a majority of attendees; as a result, the International Gypsy 
Committee (founded in 1965) was renamed the Komiteto Lumniako Romano 
(International Rom Committee).[3]﻿

My great grandfather was a Slovakian gypsy who immigrated to The 
Netherlands, and married a German. He survived a concentration camp, and 
one of his sons went on to marry a Dutch girl in the late fifties. His son 
subsequently had a daughter who was born in Canada, but raised in The 
Netherlands. That daughter married an African-American soldier from 
Louisiana in the mid-eighties, and had a son born in Germany four years 
later. That son grew up in The Netherlands, and because of his father's 
military assignment, moved to the U.S. when he was thirteen. Nine years 
later, that son began traveling all over the world, ended up marrying an 
Australian girl, and moving to Brisbane, Australia. 

That son is me. Some of us have very complicated pasts, but I couldn't be 
happier to be an example of how our past doesn't define our future. It's 
actually a blessing to have a complicated past, because there's so much to 
learn from. If anything, an interesting past makes for an even more 
interesting future. ﻿

I'm an American who stayed in Europe (England, France, Belgium and the 
Netherlands) for two weeks. Even though I had spent an extremely short 
amount of time in Europe, I still had enough encounters with Gypsies to 
fully understand why the native Europeans hate the Gypsies so much. Gypsies 
were literally *everywhere* in France. I remember seeing a couple of female 
Gypsies walking around outside the Notre Dame Cathedral. One approached me 
and handed me a piece of paper that said, "I can't speak English. I need 
help. Can you please give me money?" I knew better than to give that Gypsy 
any money, because there was another female Gypsy at the Eiffel Tower who 
had done the SAME EXACT fucking thing to me earlier. I also recall seeing 
an older female Gypsy who was sitting outside the Notre Dame Cathedral. She 
was holding a sign that had the same exact diatribe and was begging for 
money (of course she pestered me for some money when I walked in and out of 
the Notre Dame Cathedral). In addition to that, my brother Spencer got 
tricked by a Gypsy. The Gypsy told Spencer to hold out his finger and the 
Gypsy braided or wove a bracelet around his wrist in like 5 seconds flat. 
The Gypsy finished the bracelet by tying it to the finger that Spencer had 
held out, and then tied that string to her own finger, trapping my brother. 
She didn't let him go until he gave her about 20-40 Euros. Apparently, 
Gypsies do that bracelet stunt all the time. I heard a story of one little 
toddler who got trapped by a Gypsy, and was crying and begging to be let go 
while the Gypsy kept him trapped. The poor boy didn't get let go until 30 
minutes later, when his parents finally found him and paid the Gypsy. But I 
digress... Later on, when we visited the Montmartre Square, a whole slew of 
male Gypsies swarmed around us. One tried to grab my friend's finger, in an 
attempt to weave a bracelet around her wrist and do the same thing that got 
done to Spencer. It was so terrifying. Naturally, my first instinct was to 
swat the Gypsies' hand away and scream "No" multiple times. I was pretty 
blunt and shrill. But how couldn't I be? It was just so chaotic...

By the way, anybody here who thinks that what I'm saying about the Gypsies 
is bullshit really need to research Gypsy culture more deeply. Gypsies are 
a nomadic people who DO NOT have any good work ethic at all. Before anyone 
jumps to conclusions, I'm not talking about any Eugenics bullshit. I'm not 
saying that there is anything genetically or biologically wrong with 
Gypsies that make them lazier. What I'm saying is the the Gypsy *culture* 
itself fosters laziness. From their childhood onward, Gypsies are gradually 
brainwashed to be self-entitled parasites who believe that hard work and 
integrity aren't important. Gypsies absolutely refuse to make any 
contributions to society or pursue a career; they just get all of their 
possessions through deception, dishonesty or theft--hardly ever through any 
act that is actually lawful or ethical. These Gypsies even refuse to let 
their children go to school. You know why? Because Gypsies believe that 
they are entitled to money and possessions, and that they shouldn't have to 
receive an education that allows them to have a career. The mentality of 
Gypsies can be summed up as: "Well, we don't *have* to work hard to make a 
lot of money or buy a lot of luxuries. We can always get anything we want 
through deceptive, less strenuous means that don't require as much work, 
like pick-pocketing, begging, tricking people or relying on welfare. Yea, 
let's just do that!" And that's exactly what they do. 

Mark my words, any person here who says "Europe must accept Gypsies!" is 
extremely naive and has NO idea what they're talking about. I especially 
can't stand people who say this yet have never been to Europe; you people 
have the gall to act like you're so enlightened about how Gypsies in Europe 
live when you've never even *been* to Europe? Wow, just fuck off, you 
arrogant assholes. Nobody needs to hear you pretentious fuckers parrot the 
nauseating diatribe of your leftist ideology; nobody needs to hear you 
robotically talk about how how good diversity and tolerance are, and how 
evil Europeans/whites, males and Christians are. We've all heard it before. 
I'm a 19 year old white American female, and I've been hearing this 
anti-white, anti-Christian, anti-male hate speech all my life (I'm not even 
a male nor a Christian, but I'm still bothered by the hate that Christians 
and males seem to receive from our left-wing media), and I'm fed up with 
it! Enough is enough. Bigotry and nationalism are sometimes 
justified--especially for nationalities and cultures that receive hate ALL 
THE FUCKING TIME. For instance, European countries receive hate every time 
they try to preserve their culture and defend it from third world Arab and 
African immigrants (most of whom are radical Muslims who want to impose 
Sharia Law on the European people) who refuse to assimilate, yet 
"non-white" countries such as Japan, China or Mexico don't receive hate 
whenever they put restrictions on their immigration influx. Hmm, I wonder 
why. Double standards or hypocrisy perhaps?

Here is the bottom line: the Gypsy culture is a culture that is 
distinguished by dishonesty, deception, and parasitic behavior. This is not 
a stereotype. This is not a generalization. This is a FACT. It may sound 
harsh, but this is the truth. And you know what they say: the truth hurts. ﻿

I've known plenty of Roma, that have indeed integrated into societies and 
done so really well too, but then i also see the general Roma population 
being what it is. There is no persecution against Roma where i live, nor 
has there ever really been.
As i see it, the issue stems from their culture, which, unlike any other 
culture in Europe, has nomadic roots. Settling down, building a home, 
getting a regular job with a steady income and fitting in a community just 
aren't things they work towards. To add to that, their culture makes their 
communities extremely self-isolating, condemning mingling with outsiders.
The few Roma, that have integrated, all have one thing in common - they 
have abandoned their culture and assimilated in the local one. Hell, they 
themselves are usually outcast from Roma communities for doing so.
I don't see a solution to this, other than them being slowly (and 
painfully) assimilated into the local cultures.﻿

I can't comment about the Roma people in Europe, but here in the U.S we do 
have some Gypsies as well. I have to say that I have only known 4 or 5 
people who openly said that they were Roma, once we had gotten better 
acquainted. Every one of these people had jobs and were definitely not 
living off the dole or off of thieving or criminal behavior. One such Roma 
person was an American-born woman who had a BSc. in nursing and was my 
supervisor when I was working in an old-folks home.

One immigrant Roma couple who had found refuge here from the war in Bosnia, 
whom I knew some years ago, told me after a very good dinner at their home 
that I was the only 'gadjo', or non-Roma person, to have ever eaten at 
their house. I was surprised at this, so I asked them why this was so. 
Their answer was that their bad experiences as Cigane in their homeland had 
made them very distrustful of non-Roma people. They then told me that they 
felt differently about me because they could tell after some months of 
acquaintance with me at work that I was, as they put it, 'neutral' about 
them being gypsies. I took that as an honor, and I also took that as a 
lesson about the systematic persecution of an entire people to the extent 
of making them deeply distrustful of outsiders.﻿

There is DEFINITELY a substantial amount of discrimination that Roma face, 
BUT there have also been countless attempts towards integration, every 
single one of them so far have failed, uniformly in Western, Northern, 
Southern and Eastern Europe.

Saying that we shouldn't expect Roma to change their culture comes from a 
place of ignorance.

1, Roma use a clan system. There are clans that are traditionally 
specialized in music, jewel crafting etc. Then there are clans specialized 
in thievery, begging and other criminal activities. Of course we should 
demand they should these cultural traits.

2, In many Roma groups child marriages, bridal sales, loan sharking etc are 
also cultural traits. Of course we should demand they'd accept to change 
these habits.

3, In countries like Spain massive efforts are being made to keep Roma 
children in school, often practically bribing the parents with cash grants 
just to get them to keep their children in school. These efforts usually 
fail as girls are pulled from school at around 13-14 and are married off, 
and are usually pregnant and with child by 15-16.

Boys also leave school by ages 14-15, for varied and usually cultural 
reasons.

It's complicated really. We certainly should certainly come up with better 
integration schemes and make the effort of applying them. But the fact 
remains that it has to be reciprocal, the Roma need to accept the fact that 
they need to make certain changes to their culture.﻿

What makes exposing this sort of thing particularly effective isn't the act 
itself nor the work that's produced, but the broader reaching conservation 
it forces people to have. Written works, videos, and media in general are 
the vehicle that exposes an audience to the subject. That being said, 
comment sections just hammer home that point. Because what's being talked 
about here and feverishly approved of would never make the cut since its 
too outlandish for a broad audience to believe.

So here's my question to Europeans: Why the fuck would you take time out of 
your day to make sure this piece includes the type of racism they 
deliberately left out for being outlandish? The generation of Americans who 
make up the majority of the audience for English-language websites have

historical references to pre-Civil Rights America and the Nazis.﻿

incapable of becoming a productive member of society and instead makes one

survive.

I'm living in a rural part of Switzerland. So far I've only had one direct 
contact to a gypsy group. A few years ago there was a huge European 
gathering (I think it was a wedding, not sure though) of gypsies supposed 
to take place right next to our village. They rented a large festival area 
nearby with toilets, showers, drinking water and a sheltered dining area. 
When the first people arrived we were showing them the place explaining to 
them the rules and what we expected them to do before they leave. They were 
VERY nice people. At least that's what I thought. On the morning of the 
fourth day we were supposed to meet with them again. Checking if everything 
is in order and clean as we had agreed upon before.

I was as if struck by lightening. There litteraly was shit everywhere exept 
for inside the toilets. On the paths, the tables, the benches, the floor, 
in the lavatory, the showers, on the parking lots EVERYWHERE. On top of 
that there was garbage on the floor, in the nearby fields, the small stream 
was congested with litter. Of course everybody had left by the time we 
arrived. Yes they had payed for the place on the first day but it costed 
more than three times that to clean it up again afterwards.

Such an experience makes it VERY hard not to become prejudiced against 
them. I would never judge a gypsy man or woman only on grounds of what I 
have experienced back then but such previously unimaginable things like 
this are very hard to forget.﻿

Vice, 

Being from the Southern part of the United States, and then moving to a 
northern European country -- I can tell you that 99.999% of the stereotypes 
one group of people have of another group of people are based of a 
character -- and while some parts might be based in reality, they are 
exaggerated, falsified, and made to demean the other group -- whomever its 
may be.  

That being said, the Roma (and Senti) are that 0.001%.  I consider myself a 
fairly liberal individual, and attempt to always give others the benefit of 
the doubt.  However, in my 3 years in Northern Europe now -- I have never 
met a member of the Roma/Senti community that doesn't attempt to extort, 
steal, or intimidate you out of your property.  Here in our nation's 
capital city, they teach their children to slice the bottom of blue jeans 
with sharp razorblades to steal wallets from men's pockets.  The will wash 
your windshield as you tell them no, and then when you refuse to pay they 
key your car as you drive off.  They chase you down the street demanding 
money, and use their children to attempt to steal your stuff.  You cannot 
hit a child, but if grown men did to others what they have these kids doing 
-- they would get hit constantly.  

Regrettably in the Western World -- due to the ominous "you're a racist" 
term being thrown around -- Police are very reluctant to do anything about 
it -- because of these bleeding heart journalism you promoted here.  In 
this video you were very keen to point out how the Mayor's story 
contradicted itself, but failed to point out that the comment that "half 
the structures in Romania are built illegally" was also BS as well.  You 
illustrated your BIAS on this topic over and over and over again in the 
film.    

You portraying UKIP as these right wing nut jobs, when, in all reality they 
are advocating for identical polices to that of Switzerland and Norway.  

Your bias here makes me ill, and instead of sending your journalist out to 
report on the, albeit sad, situation the Roma find themselves in, you 
resorted to self-confirming BIAS where you only saught the answers you 
wanted.  Shame on you. ﻿
